sections.summary: Allah invokes the angels in their organized ranks to affirm that the **One God** is the Lord of the heavens, earth, and the Easts. The lower heaven is adorned with planets and fortified against **outcast devils** who are repelled by piercing projectiles if they attempt to eavesdrop on the celestial assembly.

sections.theme: Denial of the Resurrection and Judgment
sections.summary: Disbelievers ridicule the **Resurrection** as magic and are warned that a single nudge will usher them into the **Day of Judgment** to face their denial. On this Day, wrongdoers and their false deities are stopped for questioning, where they blame one another before sharing a common **punishment**.

The **sincere servants of Allah** are granted a known provision of delicious fruit and pure, non-intoxicating drink in the Gardens of Bliss. They enjoy the company of bashful women and reflect with gratitude on their salvation from the **pit of Hell** through divine grace.

sections.theme: The Tree of Bitterness and Deviation
sections.summary: In contrast to Paradise, the **Tree of Bitterness (Zaqqum)** serves as an ordeal for the unjust, growing from the bottom of Hell with heads like devils. Sinners are forced to eat from it and consume boiling liquid because they followed the **astray** path of their ancestors without reflection.

Noah’s appeal is answered by the Best of Responders, resulting in his survival and the preservation of his **descendants**. He is awarded **peace** among all later generations as a reward for his status as a believing servant.

Abraham denounces the manufacture of idols and is eventually tested by a dream in which he must sacrifice his son. Both submit to the **Divine Will**, leading Allah to redeem the boy with a great sacrifice and reward Abraham with the prophecy of **Isaac**.
Allah delivers Moses, Aaron, and their people from a terrible disaster and supports them to become **victors**. They are granted the **Clarifying Scripture** to guide them upon the straight path.

Elijah challenges his community for forsaking the **Best of Creators** in favor of Baal, warning them of being brought forward for judgment. His commitment to the truth earns him a noble reputation and **peace** among the righteous.

sections.theme: Lot and the Annihilation of Sinners
sections.summary: Lot and his family are rescued, with the exception of his wife who remained with those destined for **annihilation**. The site of their destruction remains as a sign for those who travel by morning and night.

sections.theme: Jonah’s Repentance and the Believing Town
sections.summary: Jonah flees his duty and is swallowed by a fish, finding deliverance only through his constant **praising** of Allah. He is subsequently sent to a community of over one hundred thousand who **believe**, sparing them from immediate ruin.

The text critiques the polytheistic logic of assigning daughters to Allah and sons to themselves, labeling such claims as **fabrications**. Allah is glorified and declared free from any relationship with the jinn or the need for **offspring**.

False gods and their worshipers are unable to seduce anyone away from Allah except those destined for **roasting in Hell**. The surah concludes by affirming the victory of the messengers and their **supporting troops**, while offering final praise to the Lord of the Worlds.
